results.title: Philharmonic safari: the London Philharmonic Orchestra "down under"
results.creator_credit: Don Shepherd and Shepherd Baker Studios
results.brief_description: A magical documentary where the story is told through the combination of stunning images, beautiful sounds of orchestral music, and minimal commentary. It is a contrast of seasons and of cultures - winter in London, summer in Australia. This is a musical journey that takes you half-way around the globe with one of the world’s greatest orchestras, the London Philharmonic Orchestra. The story begins in a snow-covered wintery London with a performance by the London Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Klaus Tennstedt, at the Royal Festival Hall. Next, the orchestra boards a Qantas flight bound for Perth and their final destination, the magnificent Leeuwin Estate, a vineyard 250 kilometres south of Perth. It is here under the Australian night sky that the London Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Avi Ostrowski, will perform to an audience of around 4,500 enthusiastic and appreciative music lovers.

results.title: The Sydney Opera House Tenth Anniversary Recital: Roger Woodward
results.creator_credit: Peter Skillman, Peter Abbott and Yoho Productions
results.brief_description: Roper Woodward played the first recital at the Sydney Opera House in 1973 and ten years later he was given the honour of performing the tenth anniversary recital on October 1, 1983. This video presents Roger Woodward performing the commemorative tenth recital live at the Sydney Opera House playing three of Beethoven’s sonatas and ending with an encore of Chopin’s Grand Waltz.

results.title: Howard Taylor
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Painters, the sculptors: archival art series”.
Howard Taylor discusses his concern with light, the relationship between sculpture and painting, his early years as an art student and prisoner of war, and the techniques he uses to create works ranging from tempera paintings to large-scale public sculptures. He expresses his special relationship with nature. Interviewed by James Murdoch.

results.title: Sam Fullbrook
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Painters, the sculptors: archival art series”.
Sam Fullbrook enjoyed a high reputation in the Australian art world for his painting as a colourist and mastery of the science of light and colour in his painting. Well travelled throughout Australia ‘teaming up’ on jobs such as mustering, jackarooing, labouring and house painting in the 1920’s-1950’s Fullbrook talks of the influences to him as painter: the light in the landscape, the spiritually ‘aristocratic ‘ nature of Aboriginal culture and house painting as one of the disciplines that he modelled his painting on. This documentary conversation with Fullbrook was taped over 17-18th December in Oakey, Queensland, 1985 and offers an insight to an artist living in Australia during very different times than today. As much as a portrait of the artist, this documentary offers as a primary source insights into a way of life unique to Australians during the depression and the post-war era.

results.title: It's up to us
results.brief_description: The Intellectual Disability Rights service have produced this video to help disabled people to deal with rights and responsibilities at work. It includes issues such as safety, sexual harrassment, the right to be treated fairly, the right to choose your own friends and to have relationships. The second section looks at why people may want a workers committee and how one group of workers set one up.

results.title: For today, for tomorrow: new choices for older Australians
results.creator_credit: Maria Taylor and Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health in association with National Recording Studios Canberra
results.brief_description: Through the lives of five older Australians, this program explores the Commonwealth Governments’ new directions for aged care services. The services featured include Home & Community Care services that allow people to remain in their own homes, the Geriatric Assessment Teams that assist individuals and their families in making informed choices and then co-ordinate the services, and a new range of choices for hostels and nursing homes. Discusses programs that address special needs such as those of older migrants. Narrated by June Salter.

results.title: Go for it!
results.creator_credit: Clayton Jacobson and Barwon Youth Employment Office for the Employment Access Program, Community Services Victoria
results.brief_description: A program aimed at young disadvantaged youth in the labour market, particularly those attending Youth Training Centres, Youth Welfare Services, living in hostels or in the care and custody of Community Services Victoria. Highlights young people succeeding in various jobs and through interviews discusses how they found employment, their expectations and experiences in the workforce.

results.title: Appearances can deceive: offenders with intellectual disabilities
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Baker, New South Wales Film Corporation, New South Wales. Premier's Dept. Disability Services Co-ordination Unit and Suzanne Baker Productions
results.brief_description: Designed to improve awareness of intellectually disabled offenders in the criminal justice system, given that this group comprise a disproportionate percentage of both the prison population and juvenile offenders held in institutions. Re-enacts a shop lifting offence by an intellectually disabled youth and follows the case from initial apprehension by the store detective and police interviewing to the arrest and court proceedings. Emphasises the importance of liason with community agencies.

results.title: Concrete city
results.creator_credit: Fabio Cavadini, Mandy King and Frontyard Films
results.brief_description: This thought-provoking film about a small community of working class people who live in the old wharfside Sydney suburb of Pyrmont, brings into question the notion of coummunity participation in major urban development schemes. The development, in this case, involves nothing less than the total destruction of a community and of valuable heritage sites, for the construction of a casino and a whole range of high rise commercial development. The community is “consulted” and “involved”, yet their own suggestions as to how best develop the area are largely ignored.

results.title: Spitfire over Australia
results.brief_description: During World War II, more than 650 Spitfire aircraft were delivered to the RAAF. This is the story of Colin Pay, who rebuilt one of those magnificent machines, a Vickers Supermarine Spitfire HF Mk VIII built in 1944, from the corroded hulk he acquired in 1982. It is now a superbly restored flying machine. Including some of the best air to air colour footage ever shot of a Spitfire in Australia, and archival footage of Spitfires in Darwin in 1943 and interviews with the pilots who originally flew them, this is the ideal video for avaition enthusiasts!
